Rationale
Firstly, the change (back) to Semester 1 is important for a new approved degree in Veterinary Conservation Medicine.
Secondly, the change of exam:CA weighting is as recommended by the School’s Board of Study to provide consistency of student experience across LIFE modules.
More details...
[1] The 1yr intercalated BSc programme in Veterinary Conservation Medicine has been run successfully by UoL between 2001 and 2010 and it is the wish of the School of Veterinary Science to reinstate the course to attract students to the UoL BVSc, with the first student uptake in 2017/2018. The requirement for acceptance onto the course is completion of at least two full years of BVSc-studies or a related discipline, and the students typically have no formal training in Conservation Biology. Five of the 6 modules on the programme depend on the students possessing, or simultaneously developing, general knowledge and skills in Conservation Biology; this is particularly so for VECM301 and VECM302, which are relying on Problem-Based Learning, but also for VECM303 (Zoo welfare and management study), VECM304 (Veterinary Conservation Medicine placement) and VECM305 (Research project). Therefore a module providing robust training in fundamental principles in Conservation Biology is critical either as a co- or pre-requisite module. LIFE326 is currently the only suitable module offered at UoL. As VECM301, VECM305 are scheduled for semester 1, the Vet Cons Med course is therefore only viable if LIFE326 is moved from semester 2 (when it is currently offered) to semester 1 (when it was offered until recently).

IMPLICATIONS FOR SOLS AND ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCE STUDENTS:
Within SOLS, this module is currently predominantly taken by students on the Zoology and Biological Sciences programs. The relevant programme directors, Susanne Voelkel and Zenobia Lewis, have been consulted and did not think that their students would be adversely affected: they considered that interested students would still have enough module choice in semester 2.
We have consulted with Programme Directors at the School of Environmental Science and identified three as potentially affected, Dr James Lea (Director for the BSc in Environmental Science [F750]), Dr Jonathan Green (Director for the BSc in Marine Biology [C160]) and Prof Rob Marrs (Director for BSc/M Ecol Ecology & the Environment [C192/C180]). I have made them aware of the plans to move LIFE326 and asked whether this would be acceptable from their perspectives. They all say that it would be although it is not ideal as it causes a bit of module congestion.
Dr James Lea says that LIFE326 is not currently part of the programme structure for BSc in Environmental Science, and to the extent that it will leave students with more options of interest in semester 1 than semester 2, he is hopeful that he can compensate for this as he is currently looking into the programme structure.
Dr Jonathan Green mentions that many students may want to take LIFE326 as well as his module ENVS310 (and it seems a third unnamed module), which would then run simultaneously in semester 1. However, he says that they would still be able to do that - and that it may in fact have the advantage that it could leave more time for project work in semester 2, a positive as in his experience the students are usually slow in starting the projects.
Prof Rob Marrs also said that it may cause more congestion in semester 1 but that the students have 45 credits of choice - and that the degree was being revised anyway which could provide a long-term solution.

[2]
In 2016 the School of Life Sciences has undergone a review of its assessment strategies which involved student representatives as well as staff from across the School. The outcomes of the review were informed by a large student survey as well as a comprehensive staff consultation which also involved all programme directors and programme teams. The final recommendations were agreed by the School’s Board of Study meeting in January 2017 and aim towards a better consistency in the School’s assessment format and weighting. The recommended balance between exam and continuous assessment for third-year modules is 70:30. The length and number of questions in our existing exam is in line with the recommendation for 70% of 15 credits. Our second assignment (the essay) currently does not adhere to the guidelines on assessment currency: 25% for a 1500 words essay is high, but 20% would be in line with the currency.

Notes
This module is due to commence in September 2017

Overview

Overview
This module employs research-based teaching to investigate contemporary ideas in conservation biology. It examines biodiversity patterns and prompts students to critically assess the evidence behind various explanations for the extinction or decline of numerous animal and plant species. Additionally, it empowers students to analyse different strategies for biodiversity conservation.

The module is delivered through lectures and student-led seminars structured as debates. To foster independent learning, students will receive direction to relevant sections of specific textbooks and are expected to pursue references, as well as primary and secondary sources provided by the instructors
Educational Aims
To develop in students the ability to explore current thinking and research in conservation biology;

To develop in students knowledge and understanding about patterns of biodiversity and to enable them to critically evaluate the evidence supporting alternative explanations for the extinctions or demise of many animal and some plant species;

To develop in students knowledge and deep understanding in conservation biology, and ability to apply, critically evaluate and interpret this knowledge to solve complex problems.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module uses research-led teaching to explore current thinking in conservation biology;

The module explores patterns of biodiversity and encourages students to critically evaluate the evidence supporting alternative explanations for the extinctions or demise of many animal and plant species;

It also enables students to critically evaluate different approaches to conserving biodiversity;

The module is taught via lectures and student led seminars, in the form of debates. To support independent learning, students will also be guided to sections of specific textbooks and expected to follow up references, primary and secondary sources, listed by staff.
Outline Syllabus
Biodiversity and biodiversity loss;

Overexploitation of wildlife populations;

Climate change impacts;

Habitat loss and disturbance;

Metapopulations;

Conservation genetics;

Prioritizing choices of species and protected areas;

Ecosystem services;

Economics of conservation;

Conservation practice in the UK and in developing countries;

Lessons from past extinctions;

Conservation and agriculture;

Species re-introductions;

Accidental introductions.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1 - Lecture
Description: This refers to timetabled online lectures in which key concepts are explained and active learning tasks are set.
Attendance Recorded: No

Teaching Method 2 - Seminar
Description: This refers to timetabled online seminars with a variety of interactive content. 5 of these sessions will include debates presented by groups of students. Others will include feedback on active learning tasks and coursework, and answering questions from students.
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 3 - Tutorials
Description: This refers to face-to-face tutorials with 1/5 of the class at a time, to help the groups prepare for their specific debate and essay topic.

Learning and teaching in this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (‘Research-connected teaching’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Delivery methods may include PBL, flipped classrooms, polling, and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework.

Lecture, tutorial and workshop content, reading lists, and discussion between students and staff give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship and Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
The open book coursework task will require students to synthesise several of the topics and concepts taught in lectures. Assessment 2 is an essay, based on primary literature and fully referenced, explaining both sides of a "great conservation debate" topic, selected from five available topics.
Students will form into groups to prepare an active debate of the issues in front of the rest of the class: this formative exercise will help to ensure their essays’ arguments stand up to scrutiny.

The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Specifically, these assessments enhance digital fluency in our students and critical thinking, skills highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their field. These authentic assessments are research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 ​To construct justified arguments for the value of conserving biodiversity
 LO2 ​To evaluate the human activities that affect biodiversity and describe how they act individually and in combination to affect individuals, populations and ecosystems
 LO3 ​To evaluate, using case studies, the pros and cons of a wide range of conservation interventions, from international legal instruments to local habitat management
 LO4 ​To analyze where conservation questions can be answered with scientific evidence, and where socio-economic and other types of information are more important

Skills

 S2 ​​Communication skills
 S3 ​​Ethical awareness

Biosciences
Rationale
Firstly, the change (back) to Semester 1 is important for a new approved degree in Veterinary Conservation Medicine.
Secondly, the change of exam:CA weighting is as recommended by the School’s Board of Study to provide consistency of student experience across LIFE modules.
More details...
[1] The 1yr intercalated BSc programme in Veterinary Conservation Medicine has been run successfully by UoL between 2001 and 2010 and it is the wish of the School of Veterinary Science to reinstate the course to attract students to the UoL BVSc, with the first student uptake in 2017/2018. The requirement for acceptance onto the course is completion of at least two full years of BVSc-studies or a related discipline, and the students typically have no formal training in Conservation Biology. Five of the 6 modules on the programme depend on the students possessing, or simultaneously developing, general knowledge and skills in Conservation Biology; this is particularly so for VECM301 and VECM302, which are relying on Problem-Based Learning, but also for VECM303 (Zoo welfare and management study), VECM304 (Veterinary Conservation Medicine placement) and VECM305 (Research project). Therefore a module providing robust training in fundamental principles in Conservation Biology is critical either as a co- or pre-requisite module. LIFE326 is currently the only suitable module offered at UoL. As VECM301, VECM305 are scheduled for semester 1, the Vet Cons Med course is therefore only viable if LIFE326 is moved from semester 2 (when it is currently offered) to semester 1 (when it was offered until recently).

IMPLICATIONS FOR SOLS AND ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCE STUDENTS:
Within SOLS, this module is currently predominantly taken by students on the Zoology and Biological Sciences programs. The relevant programme directors, Susanne Voelkel and Zenobia Lewis, have been consulted and did not think that their students would be adversely affected: they considered that interested students would still have enough module choice in semester 2.
We have consulted with Programme Directors at the School of Environmental Science and identified three as potentially affected, Dr James Lea (Director for the BSc in Environmental Science [F750]), Dr Jonathan Green (Director for the BSc in Marine Biology [C160]) and Prof Rob Marrs (Director for BSc/M Ecol Ecology & the Environment [C192/C180]). I have made them aware of the plans to move LIFE326 and asked whether this would be acceptable from their perspectives. They all say that it would be although it is not ideal as it causes a bit of module congestion.
Dr James Lea says that LIFE326 is not currently part of the programme structure for BSc in Environmental Science, and to the extent that it will leave students with more options of interest in semester 1 than semester 2, he is hopeful that he can compensate for this as he is currently looking into the programme structure.
Dr Jonathan Green mentions that many students may want to take LIFE326 as well as his module ENVS310 (and it seems a third unnamed module), which would then run simultaneously in semester 1. However, he says that they would still be able to do that - and that it may in fact have the advantage that it could leave more time for project work in semester 2, a positive as in his experience the students are usually slow in starting the projects.
Prof Rob Marrs also said that it may cause more congestion in semester 1 but that the students have 45 credits of choice - and that the degree was being revised anyway which could provide a long-term solution.

[2]
In 2016 the School of Life Sciences has undergone a review of its assessment strategies which involved student representatives as well as staff from across the School. The outcomes of the review were informed by a large student survey as well as a comprehensive staff consultation which also involved all programme directors and programme teams. The final recommendations were agreed by the School’s Board of Study meeting in January 2017 and aim towards a better consistency in the School’s assessment format and weighting. The recommended balance between exam and continuous assessment for third-year modules is 70:30. The length and number of questions in our existing exam is in line with the recommendation for 70% of 15 credits. Our second assignment (the essay) currently does not adhere to the guidelines on assessment currency: 25% for a 1500 words essay is high, but 20% would be in line with the currency.

LIFE326
Notes
This module is due to commence in September 2017

Overview

Overview
This module employs research-based teaching to investigate contemporary ideas in conservation biology. It examines biodiversity patterns and prompts students to critically assess the evidence behind various explanations for the extinction or decline of numerous animal and plant species. Additionally, it empowers students to analyse different strategies for biodiversity conservation.

The module is delivered through lectures and student-led seminars structured as debates. To foster independent learning, students will receive direction to relevant sections of specific textbooks and are expected to pursue references, as well as primary and secondary sources provided by the instructors
Educational Aims
To develop in students the ability to explore current thinking and research in conservation biology;

To develop in students knowledge and understanding about patterns of biodiversity and to enable them to critically evaluate the evidence supporting alternative explanations for the extinctions or demise of many animal and some plant species;

To develop in students knowledge and deep understanding in conservation biology, and ability to apply, critically evaluate and interpret this knowledge to solve complex problems.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module uses research-led teaching to explore current thinking in conservation biology;

The module explores patterns of biodiversity and encourages students to critically evaluate the evidence supporting alternative explanations for the extinctions or demise of many animal and plant species;

It also enables students to critically evaluate different approaches to conserving biodiversity;

The module is taught via lectures and student led seminars, in the form of debates. To support independent learning, students will also be guided to sections of specific textbooks and expected to follow up references, primary and secondary sources, listed by staff.
Outline Syllabus
Biodiversity and biodiversity loss;

Overexploitation of wildlife populations;

Climate change impacts;

Habitat loss and disturbance;

Metapopulations;

Conservation genetics;

Prioritizing choices of species and protected areas;

Ecosystem services;

Economics of conservation;

Conservation practice in the UK and in developing countries;

Lessons from past extinctions;

Conservation and agriculture;

Species re-introductions;

Accidental introductions.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1 - Lecture
Description: This refers to timetabled online lectures in which key concepts are explained and active learning tasks are set.
Attendance Recorded: No

Teaching Method 2 - Seminar
Description: This refers to timetabled online seminars with a variety of interactive content. 5 of these sessions will include debates presented by groups of students. Others will include feedback on active learning tasks and coursework, and answering questions from students.
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 3 - Tutorials
Description: This refers to face-to-face tutorials with 1/5 of the class at a time, to help the groups prepare for their specific debate and essay topic.

Learning and teaching in this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (‘Research-connected teaching’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Delivery methods may include PBL, flipped classrooms, polling, and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework.

Lecture, tutorial and workshop content, reading lists, and discussion between students and staff give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship and Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
The open book coursework task will require students to synthesise several of the topics and concepts taught in lectures. Assessment 2 is an essay, based on primary literature and fully referenced, explaining both sides of a "great conservation debate" topic, selected from five available topics.
Students will form into groups to prepare an active debate of the issues in front of the rest of the class: this formative exercise will help to ensure their essays’ arguments stand up to scrutiny.

The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Specifically, these assessments enhance digital fluency in our students and critical thinking, skills highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their field. These authentic assessments are research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 ​To construct justified arguments for the value of conserving biodiversity
 LO2 ​To evaluate the human activities that affect biodiversity and describe how they act individually and in combination to affect individuals, populations and ecosystems
 LO3 ​To evaluate, using case studies, the pros and cons of a wide range of conservation interventions, from international legal instruments to local habitat management
 LO4 ​To analyze where conservation questions can be answered with scientific evidence, and where socio-economic and other types of information are more important
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 ​​Problem solving skills
 S2 ​​Communication skills
 S3 ​​Ethical awareness

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 ​To construct justified arguments for the value of conserving biodiversity
 LO2 ​To evaluate the human activities that affect biodiversity and describe how they act individually and in combination to affect individuals, populations and ecosystems
 LO3 ​To evaluate, using case studies, the pros and cons of a wide range of conservation interventions, from international legal instruments to local habitat management
 LO4 ​To analyze where conservation questions can be answered with scientific evidence, and where socio-economic and other types of information are more important
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 ​​Problem solving skills
 S2 ​​Communication skills
 S3 ​​Ethical awareness

Rationale
Firstly, the change (back) to Semester 1 is important for a new approved degree in Veterinary Conservation Medicine.
Secondly, the change of exam:CA weighting is as recommended by the School’s Board of Study to provide consistency of student experience across LIFE modules.
More details...
[1] The 1yr intercalated BSc programme in Veterinary Conservation Medicine has been run successfully by UoL between 2001 and 2010 and it is the wish of the School of Veterinary Science to reinstate the course to attract students to the UoL BVSc, with the first student uptake in 2017/2018. The requirement for acceptance onto the course is completion of at least two full years of BVSc-studies or a related discipline, and the students typically have no formal training in Conservation Biology. Five of the 6 modules on the programme depend on the students possessing, or simultaneously developing, general knowledge and skills in Conservation Biology; this is particularly so for VECM301 and VECM302, which are relying on Problem-Based Learning, but also for VECM303 (Zoo welfare and management study), VECM304 (Veterinary Conservation Medicine placement) and VECM305 (Research project). Therefore a module providing robust training in fundamental principles in Conservation Biology is critical either as a co- or pre-requisite module. LIFE326 is currently the only suitable module offered at UoL. As VECM301, VECM305 are scheduled for semester 1, the Vet Cons Med course is therefore only viable if LIFE326 is moved from semester 2 (when it is currently offered) to semester 1 (when it was offered until recently).

IMPLICATIONS FOR SOLS AND ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCE STUDENTS:
Within SOLS, this module is currently predominantly taken by students on the Zoology and Biological Sciences programs. The relevant programme directors, Susanne Voelkel and Zenobia Lewis, have been consulted and did not think that their students would be adversely affected: they considered that interested students would still have enough module choice in semester 2.
We have consulted with Programme Directors at the School of Environmental Science and identified three as potentially affected, Dr James Lea (Director for the BSc in Environmental Science [F750]), Dr Jonathan Green (Director for the BSc in Marine Biology [C160]) and Prof Rob Marrs (Director for BSc/M Ecol Ecology & the Environment [C192/C180]). I have made them aware of the plans to move LIFE326 and asked whether this would be acceptable from their perspectives. They all say that it would be although it is not ideal as it causes a bit of module congestion.
Dr James Lea says that LIFE326 is not currently part of the programme structure for BSc in Environmental Science, and to the extent that it will leave students with more options of interest in semester 1 than semester 2, he is hopeful that he can compensate for this as he is currently looking into the programme structure.
Dr Jonathan Green mentions that many students may want to take LIFE326 as well as his module ENVS310 (and it seems a third unnamed module), which would then run simultaneously in semester 1. However, he says that they would still be able to do that - and that it may in fact have the advantage that it could leave more time for project work in semester 2, a positive as in his experience the students are usually slow in starting the projects.
Prof Rob Marrs also said that it may cause more congestion in semester 1 but that the students have 45 credits of choice - and that the degree was being revised anyway which could provide a long-term solution.

[2]
In 2016 the School of Life Sciences has undergone a review of its assessment strategies which involved student representatives as well as staff from across the School. The outcomes of the review were informed by a large student survey as well as a comprehensive staff consultation which also involved all programme directors and programme teams. The final recommendations were agreed by the School’s Board of Study meeting in January 2017 and aim towards a better consistency in the School’s assessment format and weighting. The recommended balance between exam and continuous assessment for third-year modules is 70:30. The length and number of questions in our existing exam is in line with the recommendation for 70% of 15 credits. Our second assignment (the essay) currently does not adhere to the guidelines on assessment currency: 25% for a 1500 words essay is high, but 20% would be in line with the currency.

LIFE326
Notes
This module is due to commence in September 2017

Overview

Overview
This module employs research-based teaching to investigate contemporary ideas in conservation biology. It examines biodiversity patterns and prompts students to critically assess the evidence behind various explanations for the extinction or decline of numerous animal and plant species. Additionally, it empowers students to analyse different strategies for biodiversity conservation.

The module is delivered through lectures and student-led seminars structured as debates. To foster independent learning, students will receive direction to relevant sections of specific textbooks and are expected to pursue references, as well as primary and secondary sources provided by the instructors
Educational Aims
To develop in students the ability to explore current thinking and research in conservation biology;

To develop in students knowledge and understanding about patterns of biodiversity and to enable them to critically evaluate the evidence supporting alternative explanations for the extinctions or demise of many animal and some plant species;

To develop in students knowledge and deep understanding in conservation biology, and ability to apply, critically evaluate and interpret this knowledge to solve complex problems.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module uses research-led teaching to explore current thinking in conservation biology;

The module explores patterns of biodiversity and encourages students to critically evaluate the evidence supporting alternative explanations for the extinctions or demise of many animal and plant species;

It also enables students to critically evaluate different approaches to conserving biodiversity;

The module is taught via lectures and student led seminars, in the form of debates. To support independent learning, students will also be guided to sections of specific textbooks and expected to follow up references, primary and secondary sources, listed by staff.
Outline Syllabus
Biodiversity and biodiversity loss;

Overexploitation of wildlife populations;

Climate change impacts;

Habitat loss and disturbance;

Metapopulations;

Conservation genetics;

Prioritizing choices of species and protected areas;

Ecosystem services;

Economics of conservation;

Conservation practice in the UK and in developing countries;

Lessons from past extinctions;

Conservation and agriculture;

Species re-introductions;

Accidental introductions.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1 - Lecture
Description: This refers to timetabled online lectures in which key concepts are explained and active learning tasks are set.
Attendance Recorded: No

Teaching Method 2 - Seminar
Description: This refers to timetabled online seminars with a variety of interactive content. 5 of these sessions will include debates presented by groups of students. Others will include feedback on active learning tasks and coursework, and answering questions from students.
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 3 - Tutorials
Description: This refers to face-to-face tutorials with 1/5 of the class at a time, to help the groups prepare for their specific debate and essay topic.

Learning and teaching in this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (‘Research-connected teaching’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Delivery methods may include PBL, flipped classrooms, polling, and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework.

Lecture, tutorial and workshop content, reading lists, and discussion between students and staff give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship and Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
The open book coursework task will require students to synthesise several of the topics and concepts taught in lectures. Assessment 2 is an essay, based on primary literature and fully referenced, explaining both sides of a "great conservation debate" topic, selected from five available topics.
Students will form into groups to prepare an active debate of the issues in front of the rest of the class: this formative exercise will help to ensure their essays’ arguments stand up to scrutiny.

The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Specifically, these assessments enhance digital fluency in our students and critical thinking, skills highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their field. These authentic assessments are research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

The module explores patterns of biodiversity and encourages students to critically evaluate the evidence supporting alternative explanations for the extinctions or demise of many animal and plant species;

It also enables students to critically evaluate different approaches to conserving biodiversity;

The module is taught via lectures and student led seminars, in the form of debates. To support independent learning, students will also be guided to sections of specific textbooks and expected to follow up references, primary and secondary sources, listed by staff.
Outline Syllabus
Biodiversity and biodiversity loss;

Overexploitation of wildlife populations;

Climate change impacts;

Habitat loss and disturbance;

Metapopulations;

Conservation genetics;

Prioritizing choices of species and protected areas;

Ecosystem services;

Economics of conservation;

Conservation practice in the UK and in developing countries;

Lessons from past extinctions;

Conservation and agriculture;

Species re-introductions;

Accidental introductions.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1 - Lecture
Description: This refers to timetabled online lectures in which key concepts are explained and active learning tasks are set.
Attendance Recorded: No

Teaching Method 2 - Seminar
Description: This refers to timetabled online seminars with a variety of interactive content. 5 of these sessions will include debates presented by groups of students. Others will include feedback on active learning tasks and coursework, and answering questions from students.
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 3 - Tutorials
Description: This refers to face-to-face tutorials with 1/5 of the class at a time, to help the groups prepare for their specific debate and essay topic.

Learning and teaching in this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (‘Research-connected teaching’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Delivery methods may include PBL, flipped classrooms, polling, and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework.

Lecture, tutorial and workshop content, reading lists, and discussion between students and staff give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship and Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
The open book coursework task will require students to synthesise several of the topics and concepts taught in lectures. Assessment 2 is an essay, based on primary literature and fully referenced, explaining both sides of a "great conservation debate" topic, selected from five available topics.
Students will form into groups to prepare an active debate of the issues in front of the rest of the class: this formative exercise will help to ensure their essays’ arguments stand up to scrutiny.

The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Specifically, these assessments enhance digital fluency in our students and critical thinking, skills highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their field. These authentic assessments are research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 ​To construct justified arguments for the value of conserving biodiversity
 LO2 ​To evaluate the human activities that affect biodiversity and describe how they act individually and in combination to affect individuals, populations and ecosystems
 LO3 ​To evaluate, using case studies, the pros and cons of a wide range of conservation interventions, from international legal instruments to local habitat management
 LO4 ​To analyze where conservation questions can be answered with scientific evidence, and where socio-economic and other types of information are more important
